big_picture_notes: Micah is structured as a tripartite cycle—Judgment (1–3), Restoration (4–5), and Reconciliation (6–7)—framed by three major 'Hear' oracles (1:2; 3:1; 6:1). The literary engine is the covenant‑lawsuit (rîb), moving repeatedly from indictment to sentence to salvation. Devices include dramatic contrast (predatory rulers vs. future shepherd‑king), paronomasia on town names (1:10–16), dialogic exchanges among God, prophet, people, and personified Zion, and climactic ethical summary (6:8). The book resolves in a confessional lament and doxology (7:7–20), affirming Yahweh’s covenant loyalty.

stories.story_title: The Lord's Covenant Lawsuit Against Samaria and Jerusalem
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: First major oracle cycle: superscription and universal summons (1:1–2) → Yahweh’s descent and Samaria’s ruin (1:3–7) → prophet’s lament with town‑name wordplay (1:8–16) → social indictment and sentence (2:1–11) → abrupt salvation oracle (2:12–13). Glue: divine descent/destruction imagery and paronomasia chain binding 1:8–16; closes with the 'Breaker' and 'Yahweh at their head.'

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Superscription/oracle formula; Yahweh comes forth, mountains melt; concludes with Samaria’s specific demolition and idol‑wealth exposed. Devices: theophany, rhetorical question (1:5), devastation imagery.

scenes.scene_name: The Prophet's Lament and Town Puns
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Speaker shifts to prophet’s hyperbolic grief; series of paronomasia on town names announces cascading losses; ends with shaved head over exiled children. Devices: lament form, wordplay chain, imperatives.

scenes.scene_name: The Masters of Iniquity and Their Schemes
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'Woe' indictment of land‑grabbers designing evil on beds; closes with loss of lot‑line in Yahweh’s assembly. Devices: woe oracle, inheritance reversal legalism.
Audience protests 'Do not preach'; prophet counters with questions and contrasts; ends with satire of desired wine‑preacher. Devices: dialogue, rhetorical questions, irony.
Sudden salvation oracle gathers Jacob; the 'Breaker' opens the way; 'Yahweh at their head' closes the cycle. Devices: royal/shepherd metaphors, abrupt hope pivot.

stories.story_title: The Corrupt Leaders and the Promise of the True King
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Second major cycle: leaders, prophets, priests indicted (3:1–11) culminating in Zion’s plowing (3:12); followed by expansive restoration and messianic hope (4–5), climaxing with the ruler from Bethlehem and covenant cleansing before a closing vengeance note (5:15). Glue: juxtaposition of corrupt elites with ideal shepherd‑king; Zion’s fall vs exaltation.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'Hear, heads of Jacob' opens; grotesque eating‑the‑people imagery; ends with Yahweh not answering their future cry. Devices: satire, reversal justice.
Prophets who feed get peace oracles; night without vision decreed; Micah’s Spirit‑empowered contrast ends the unit. Devices: antithetical parallelism, first‑person contrast.

scenes.scene_name: The Fall of Zion and the Ruin of the Temple
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Triad of leaders condemned; climax: Zion plowed, Jerusalem heap, temple mount forest height. Devices: ultimate reversal, legal summation.

scenes.scene_name: The Mountain of the Lord's House
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'In the latter days' pivot to exalted Zion and universal peace; ends with pledge to walk in Yahweh’s name. Devices: synonymous parallelism, swords‑to‑plowshares contrast.

scenes.scene_name: Gathering the Lame and the Outcast
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Yahweh assembles the lame/outcast remnant and restores dominion to Jerusalem; unit ends with royal assurance. Devices: remnant theology, restoration motif.
Questions announce birth‑pangs; exile to Babylon foretold, then Zion’s iron‑horn threshing victory. Devices: antithesis (anguish→triumph), time/place marker (Babylon).

scenes.scene_name: The King from Bethlehem and the Remnant
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: From siege to promise: Bethlehem produces ancient‑origin ruler who shepherds in Yahweh’s strength—'this one will be peace.' Devices: contrast of lowly origin/high office, shepherd‑king imagery.

Remnant imagery (dew/lion) and comprehensive 'I will cut off' purges (horses, cities, sorceries, idols), closing with vengeance on disobedient nations. Devices: lexical chain of cut‑offs, purification catalog.

stories.story_title: The Great Covenant Lawsuit and Final Prayer
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Third cycle: explicit rîb trial (6:1–16) followed by personal/confessional lament and prayer with doxology (7:1–20). Opens with summons to mountains and Yahweh’s historical case; climaxes in ethical triad (6:8); reaffirms judgment on commerce and Omri’s statutes; then moves to 'I will wait for Yahweh' hope, Zion’s confession and vindication, shepherd‑petition, and covenant doxology. Glue: dialogic form and first‑person turn.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Summons creation as witnesses; Yahweh’s 'O my people' questions recall righteous acts (Egypt→Gilgal); unit ends when case grounding is complete. Devices: rîb genre, historical recital.
People’s hypothetical offerings escalate to firstborn; prophet answers with triad—do justice, love hesed, walk humbly. Devices: rhetorical climax, ethical parallelism.

scenes.scene_name: The City's False Standards and Judgment
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: 'The voice of Yahweh' to the city indicts false scales and violence; ends with covenant‑reversal curses and citation of Omri/Ahab statutes. Devices: forensic oracle, measure‑for‑measure reversal.
First‑person 'woe to me' over fruitless land and broken trusts; closes in defiant faith: 'I will look to Yahweh … my God will hear me.' Devices: lament metaphor (harvest), social breakdown catalogue.

Address to enemy; confession of sin and hope in light; vision of vindication and desolation for foes—completed with land made desolate for deeds. Devices: light/darkness motif, confession‑to‑vindication arc.

scenes.scene_name: Prayer for the Shepherd and Final Doxology
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Petition to shepherd the flock; promise of marvels as in Exodus; doxology exalting God who pardons and has compassion; closes with covenant faithfulness to Jacob/Abraham. Devices: shepherd metaphor, exodus typology, doxological conclusion.
